content:
The "Responding to Urgent needs of Survivors of the Holocaust Act" or the "RUSH Act" includes provisions for defining, organizing, and implementing programs to assist Holocaust survivors. It also addresses elder abuse prevention and nutrition services for older individuals. The "RUSH Act" includes provisions for defining, organizing, and implementing programs to assist Holocaust survivors, addressing elder abuse prevention, and providing nutrition services for older individuals. The purposes of the Act include providing preference for services to older individuals who are Holocaust survivors, designating a responsible individual within the Administration on Aging for these individuals, ensuring meals meet special dietary needs, and supporting programs for mobility and self-sufficiency. During the Holocaust, an estimated 6,000,000 Jews and millions from other targeted groups were murdered by the Nazis. Over 200,000 Jews found refuge in the United States from 1933 to 1945, with more settling in the following years. Jewish refugees continued to immigrate to the US from Europe and the former Soviet Union. The Conference on Jewish Material Claims Against Germany's 2011 Worldbook provides estimates on the Nazi victim population. According to the Conference on Jewish Material Claims Against Germany's 2011 Worldbook, the estimated Nazi victim population in the United States is 120,935, with 3 in 5 victims being women. The average age of a Nazi victim is 80, and nearly one-quarter are age 85 or older. Holocaust survivors continue to live with mental and physical scars, and institutionalization can have adverse effects on them. Holocaust survivors may experience panic, anxiety, and re-traumatization in institutionalized settings due to past experiences. Findings show that survivors are economically and socially vulnerable, have poorer health, more disabilities, and rely heavily on social service programs compared to non-victims. Holocaust survivors require various services like personal care, meals, transportation, counseling, and mental health support to improve their health and quality of life. Community organizations note that two-thirds of survivors live alone, which increases the risk of hospitalization, poverty, depression, and other health issues. Many survivors, especially those who immigrated from the former Soviet Union after 1965, have low incomes. Holocaust survivors, especially those from the Soviet Union after 1965, have low incomes below the poverty threshold in the United States. Community organizations emphasize the importance of transportation for survivors to access medical appointments, shop, visit family, and participate in social events. Providers serving older adults, including Holocaust survivors, require additional capacity to meet the growing demand for services. The Administration for Community Living in the Department of Health and Human Services plays a key role in supporting these populations. The Department of Health and Human Services focuses on increasing access to community supports for older Americans and people with disabilities. The Administration for Community Living aims to enhance the well-being of older adults and individuals with disabilities. Social service agencies funded under the Older Americans Act provide specialized meals for diverse seniors with unique dietary needs. TITLE I--RESPONDING TO THE NEEDS OF HOLOCAUST SURVIVORS, Subtitle A--Definition, Grants, and Other Programs, SEC. 101. DEFINITION. Section 102 of the Older Americans Act of 1965 is amended to include the definition of a "Holocaust survivor" as an individual who lived in a country under Nazi regime, occupation, or control between 1933 and 1945. The amendment defines a "Holocaust survivor" as someone who fled from a country under Nazi regime, occupation, or control between 1933 and 1945, was persecuted on various bases, and was a member of a persecuted group by the Nazis. SEC. 102 of the Older Americans Act is amended to include "older individuals who are Holocaust survivors" in certain paragraphs. SEC. 103 pertains to area plans. Section 306 of the Older Americans Act of 1965 is amended to include "older individuals who are Holocaust survivors" in various subsections. The Older Americans Act of 1965 is amended to include "older individuals who are Holocaust survivors" in various subsections, such as subparagraphs (B)(i) and (B)(ii), as well as in paragraph (7)(B)(iii) and subsection (b)(2)(B). SEC. 104 of the Older Americans Act of 1965 is amended to include "older individuals who are Holocaust survivors" in various paragraphs, such as paragraph (4) and paragraph (16). SEC. 105 of the Older Americans Act of 1965 is amended to include "older individuals who are Holocaust survivors" in subsections (c)(2) and (d). SEC. 107 amends the Older Americans Act to include Holocaust survivors as a group requiring prevention of abuse, neglect, and exploitation. SEC. 121 authorizes the designation of a person within the Administration for Community Living to implement services for older Holocaust survivors. The Administrator for Community Living, with assistance, prepares and submits an annual report to Congress on the status and needs of older Holocaust survivors. This is part of the Nutrition Services for all older individuals. The Older Americans Act of 1965 is being amended to adjust and fund programs to meet special health-related or dietary needs, including religious, cultural, or ethnic requirements. Additionally, individuals distributing nutrition services are encouraged to engage in education under subpart 2. The Older Americans Act is being amended to fund programs meeting special dietary needs, including religious or ethnic requirements. Service providers are required to analyze their ability to obtain special foods for these needs. TITLE III--TRANSPORTATION SERVICES AND RESOURCES

Amendment to the Older Americans Act to support transportation services for older individuals with economic and social needs.
